result.execSummary:
The defendant Chad W. Meyer was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Criminal Damage to Property, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(1).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: In the event probation is revoked, Defendant would be entitled to Good Time Credit and Huber Privileges.

miscConds.notes: Court orders bond on file to be applied.   Balance of costs to be paid directly to the Waushara County Clerk of Court within 60 days or establish a payment plan.  Failure to pay may result in suspension of your driver's license, tax intercept, a civil judgment being entered against you, a warrant being issued for your arrest for contempt and/or the debt being turned over to a collection agency.

The defendant must maintain absolute sobriety, may not be present upon the premises of any bars, and is prohibited from possessing/ingesting any impairing substances that have not been prescribed by a physician. The defendant is to have NO CONTACT with S. D. as named in the complaint.

Defendant is to comply with any rules/recommendations as deemed appropriate by the supervising agent.   Defendant may petition for early termination of probation term after completion of 6 months, provided request is joined by agent and all financial obligations are paid in full and all treatment programming is completed.  DNA sample to be provided and surcharge assessed.

result.caption: State of Wisconsin vs. Chad W. Meyer

records.descr: Records of prosec. are converted data. See file.

records.addlTxt: Case Called @ 2:16 PM: Defendant Chad W. Meyer in court.  Steven Paul Anderson appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Complaint Stated - Advised of offense and minimum/maximum penalty.  Receipt Admitted - Reading Waived.  Advised of right of Counsel.  Def does not wish counsel today and is prepared to resolve the matter.  Based upon Def's wishes to resolve the matter today - State moves for dismissal of Repeater penalty enhancer asttached to Ct 1 and Ct 2 DRI.   Def would not object to motion of the State.    Defendant advised of right to counsel and expertise.  Voluntary waiver of counsel accepted by Court.  Defendant advised of minimum/maximum penalty.  Plea colloquy entertained.  Collateral consequences explained. Chapter 950 compliance addressed. Plea Ct 1 w/o Repeater Enh:  GP  Court accepts plea and enters JOC. Ct 2 DRI and Repeater component attached to Ct 1 dismissed.  ADA argues for 1 yr probation.  Statement by Def:  Def requests alternative rather than being on probation. States he has already purchased replacement item.  As of today's hearing the State has not yet rec'd a claim for Restitution - some indication that replacement item was requested.  Further statement by Defendant.  The Court:  30 days WCJ - I/S - S/W - 1 yr probation with option to terminate at completion of 6 mos if joined by agent.  Conditions:  The defendant must maintain absolute sobriety, may not be present upon the premises of any bars, and is prohibited from possessing/ingesting any impairing substances that have not been prescribed by a physician.t, No contact with S.D.; Court Costs - 60 DTP or PP with bond being applied and to include DNA Sample and Surcharge ordered by the Court.   Defendant advised of right to expunge DNA record through the Department of Justice.  Appeal Rights Given.
